questions.text: A 4-year-old girl comes to the ED with sudden onset of wheezing. The mother says she heard the wheezing right after opened up gifts. The mother states that the brother received a set of toy cars with detachable wheels. What is the most appropriate test?
questions.solution:
• This child’s history is suspicious for Foreign Body Aspiration. Plain films may be normal with FBA, but certain findings may be present that strongly support the diagnosis.
  • If children are old enough to cooperate with breath-holding, obtaining inspiratory and expiratory radiographs increases the sensitivity of identifying air trapping and local hyperinflation from foreign body obstruction.
  • Decubitus views of the chest do not require cooperation for inspiratory and expiratory breath-holding and are more useful for infants and young children. With FBA, the expected deflation of the dependent lung is not seen due to the foreign body causing air trapping.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 859)

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents with an inability to stop fidgeting for the past 6 months. Her mother states that both she and her teachers are complaining that the girl 'cannot sit still'. The nonrhythmic movement only occurs when she is awake. Her physical exam is unremarkable. The girl states that she feels as if 'bugs are crawling up her legs', and she only feels better when she moves her legs as if trying to squash them. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• RLS (Willis Ekbom syndrome) is a chronic neurologic disorder, characterized by an almost irresistible urge to move the legs, often accompanied by uncomfortable sensations in the lower extremities. Both the urge to move and the sensations are usually worse at rest and in the evening and are at least partially relieved by movement, including walking, stretching, and rubbing, but only as long as the motion continues.
  • RLS is a clinical diagnosis that is based on the presence of these key symptoms.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 119

questions.text: On exposure to cold, a 14year old girl characteristically develops pallor, then cyanosis, and finally erythema of the fingers and toes. She is at increased risk of developing
questions.solution:
• The presentation mentioned in the vignette is of Raynaud’s Phenomenon.
  • Raynaud phenomenon (RP) is the most frequent initial symptom in pediatric systemic sclerosis, present in 70% of affected children months to years before other manifestations.
  • RP refers to the classic triphasic sequence of blanching, cyanosis, and erythema of the digits induced by cold exposure and/or emotional stress. RP is most commonly independent of an underlying rheumatic disease (Raynaud disease), but it can be a consequence of rheumatic diseases such as scleroderma, systemic lupus erythematosus, and mixed connective tissue disease.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paaediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 3109

questions.text: A 12-month-old male child is brought to your office for a well-child examination and immunizations. You have been following the child since delivery and are aware that he has acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) and a markedly reduced T-cell count. Which of the following vaccinations should he not receive?
questions.solution:
• In immunocompromised patients, Live vaccines are contraindicated.
  • All of the vaccines mentioned, except varicella, are killed or synthetic vaccines.

Ref. IAP textbook on immunization

questions.text: An infant begins to have progressively large amounts of bilious emesis. The infant feeds well and has only a small amount of abdominal distention. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The infant has bilious and no diarrhea. Hence, obstruction is the etiology. (Option d ruled out)
  • As the vomiting is bilious, obstruction is beyond 2nd part of duodenum (option a ruled out)
  • Disease beyond duodenum would have abdominal distention. (Option b ruled out)

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1801

choices.text: Is usually associated with a hypoplastic left lung
Will show dextrocardia on the chest X ray as a result of situs inversus
Is associated with abnormal pulmonary arterial supply

questions.text: True statement about Scimitar syndrome
questions.solution:
• Scimitar syndrome is a form of anomalous pulmonary venous drainage in which the veins from the lower right lung drain into the inferior vena cava.
  • The right lung is hypoplastic.
  • There is associated dextrocardia due to heart moving over to the right of the chest, but with normal situs.
  • There may be associated anomalous systemic arterial supply from descending aorta or its branches to the right lung.

Ref. Park’s textbook of Paediatric Cardiology, 6th ed., pg. 182

choices.text: Typical facial features of micrognathia and long faces
Poor eye contact and social impairment
Absence of learning disability in all females

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of fragile X syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Fragile X syndrome is an X linked condition affecting 1 in 4000 males and is characterized by learning disability.
  • It causes moderate to severe learning disability in males, and can cause learning disability in carrier females.
  • It is characterized by long faces, prominent ears and jaw and macro-orchidism in post-pubertal males.
  • Behavioral characteristics includes social impairment, poor attention, and difficulty in making and sustaining eye contact.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paaediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 622

choices.text: Use index finger to point what he wants
Look for toys he has dropped
Bang together two objects in the midline

questions.text: A mother presents with her 1-year-old baby for a well-baby checkup. Which of the following developmental milestone is not expected to be achieved by the baby?
questions.solution:
• At 9 months, child will look for the toys they have dropped.
  • By 1 year, a child can bang two objects in the midline and he can feed himself a biscuit.
  • By 15 months, a child should be able to point at what he wants, using his index finger.

Ref. Illingworth’s The development of Infant & Child

choices.text: Benzyl alcohol should be avoided in injectable preparations
Propylene glycol must be avoided at any concentration

questions.text: True statement regarding drug excipients in neonates is
questions.solution:
• Benzyl alcohol can cause severe respiratory distress in neonates and hence it is avoided.
  • Propylene glycol is hypertonic, fast administration of high quantities can cause hemodynamic instability. But small amounts infused slowly are acceptable.
  • Lactose may be used in any patient, provided they are not lactose intolerant.
  • Sugar free medicines are desirable in children as sugar can cause dental caries.

Ref. Goodman & Gilman's Pharmacological basis of therapeutics, 13th ed., pg. 33

choices.text: They are usually caused by staphylococcus epidermidis
Tinea infections are usually caused by Microsporum canis
Tinea corporis will show improvement if steroid creams are applied
Scalp abscesses due to fungal infection require incision and drainage

questions.text: True statement about pediatric skin infection is
questions.solution:
• Skin infections are usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus or group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus.
  • Majority of tinea infections are due to Trichophyton species, with human-to-human spread.
  • Tinea corporis does show temporary improvement with topical steroid creams, as the redness and inflammation improve.
  • Scalp abscesses due to fungal infection are called Kerions. These should not be incised and drained, as a permanent scar will be left. The treatment of choice is antifungal therapy started without a delay.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 3215

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the casualty with 3 days of high-grade fever and erythematous rashes, peeling of skin on finger tips. Best treatment among the following is?
questions.solution:
• This is a Staphylococcal scalded-skin syndrome and treatment needs systemic antibiotics.
  • Acyclovir would be given for herpes simplex infection when the lesions at different stages would be expected in addition to erythema. Peeling is not usually found in HSV infection.
  • Methotrexate would be indicated for acute erythrodermic psoriasis.
  • Immunoglobulins would be given for Kawasaki disease; for this diagnosis a 5 days fever is required and skin peeling is a late sign, typically in the second week.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 3207

questions.text: Parents of a 3-year-old boy presents to you with concerns about his development. Antenatal and neonatal history is insignificant. He has always been slow in his development. His mother also had mild learning difficulties and needed extra help in school. On assessment he can walk but not jump. He has poor eye contact, no clear words and cannot identify body parts. He is unable to copy horizontal line and still in his diapers. Examination is difficult as he becomes very distressed and demonstrates hand flapping. His head circumference is on the 90th centile. Which of the following is the most useful investigation?
questions.solution:
• The history tells us that the child is a boy with mother with learning difficulties. This should always raise a concern regarding fragile X syndrome and Duchenne muscular dystrophy. The examination reveals a child with significant developmental delay, autistic features and a large head, all in keeping with a diagnosis of fragile X syndrome.
  • The other investigations are reasonable in the child with developmental delay but in this case are less likely to provide a diagnosis.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 622

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl had a history of sore throat and fever before 4 months. Since then, she had headaches, generalized muscle pain, tiredness and poor concentration of increasing severity. For the past 2 months, she has been unable to attend school because of her muscle pain and lethargy and her sleep pattern is disturbed. She finds it difficult to fall asleep at night and then has difficulty to wake up in the morning. On examination she has mild lymphadenopathy and pallor. Her weight is continuing on the 25th centile. Examination is otherwise unremarkable except for marked muscle pain she experiences on movement of her limbs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The lack of weight loss rules out anorexia nervosa.
  • If hypothyroidism is severe enough to cause her to take 2 months off school, her weight is expected to rise, hence it is unlikely.
  • Sleep pattern is not typical of depression, hence less likely.
  • Chronic fatigue syndrome often develops after a viral illness. It is characterized by headaches, fatigue, muscle pain, poor concentration and sleep disturbances. Pallor and cervical lymphadenopathy are common associated findings. Weight is usually static or increases mildly due to inactivity and lack of exercise.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 996

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for Growth hormone therapy?
questions.solution:
Indication for GH therapy are

  • Growth hormone deficiency
  • Turner syndrome
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Prader-Willi syndrome
  • SGA child

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2546

choices.text: Klinefelter syndrome is associated with anosmia
Marfan syndrome is associated with pneumothorax
In Soto syndrome, head circumference is proportional to length
It is associated with congenital adrenal hyperplasia

questions.text: False statement about childhood tall stature is
questions.solution:
• Klinefelter syndrome is associated with short stature.
  • Marfan syndrome is characterized by arachnodactyly, tall stature, scoliosis, high-arched palate, and joint hypermobility. Other associations are learning difficulties, lens dislocation, aortic dissection and mitral valve prolapse, and pneumothorax.
  • The androgen excess of untreated congenital adrenal hyperplasia leads to tall stature in childhood.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2649

choices.text: Presents in a similar way to rectal prolapse
Will usually not respond to pneumatic reduction

questions.text: True statement about intussusception in children is
questions.solution:
• Intussusception is characteristically disease of less than 1 year old children, though cases are observed after that too.
  • It usually presents with screaming pain, rectal bleeding and an abdominal mass. Apex of the intussusception may protrude per anus.
  • Only about 5-10% will recur whether treated with pneumatic reduction or by open surgery.
  • Closed reduction using the pneumatic technique under radiological control should have a success rate in order of 90%.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1813

choices.text: Divide the adhesion in general anesthesia

questions.text: A 6.5-year-old boy has a healthy prepuce, which is 60% adherent to glanular surface. What is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
• If preputial adhesions are separated either by physical or chemical means, the vast majority subsequently reform. Smegma may accumulate under the adherent prepuce, forming a preputial pearl. Once the adhesion resolves, this mass of secretions is extruded with the urine. This means that any invasive treatment is undesirable, and the level of undesirability is directly proportional to the invasiveness of the treatment.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2584

questions.text: True statement about Gilbert syndrome is
questions.solution:
• Gilbert syndrome is an unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia with no evidence of hemolysis. Its inheritance is autosomal dominant with incomplete expression.
  • Its pathogenesis is a mild functional deficiency of the enzyme UDP glucuronyl transferase.
  • Clinical picture is of mild fluctuating jaundice aggravated by infection, exertion and fasting.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1937

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents to you for the first time. His previous records shows that he has diagnosis of Cystic fibrosis, with CFTR gene mutation study positive. During the counselling, parents should be explained about increased risk of all except?
questions.solution:
• Children with CF are at increased risk of recurrent abdominal pain.
  • Intestinal complications include, meconium ileus, atresias, rectal prolapse, distal obstruction syndrome, and strictures secondary to high dose pancreatic supplementation.
  • Hepatobiliary complications are, cholestasis in infancy, fatty liver, focal biliary fibrosis, multi-lobular cirrhosis, cholelithiasis or obstruction of CBD.
  • Pancreatic complication are pancreatic insufficiency, pancreatitis.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2103

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is referred to you from a peripheral center with suspected peanut allergy. She is stable vitally and visited you for further management. Which of the following will be the next BEST step?
questions.solution:
• It is important to get the diagnosis right as lots of children have nonspecific reactions during childhood and are labelled peanut allergic.
  • First line investigation involves skin prick testing, as it has high sensitivity and specificity.
  • Active management involves peanut challenge in children whose skin prick test is negative.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1080

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with a 6-month history of recurrent abdominal pain. The pain occurs mostly in the evenings, just before he goes to sleep. He is not missing school. There is a past history of recurrent abdominal pain, although the last time it was a major problem was when he was 11 years. There is an abdominal mass. Basic blood test is normal. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• The presence of a mass, particularly if it will indent on palpation in a child with recurrent abdominal pain is a pointer to chronic constipation with fecal loading as a potential cause. This is a common cause of fecal mass. The blood tests would be normal.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1758

questions.text: Parents of a 4-month-old infant visits you for advice regarding formula feeds as mother has reduced amount of lactation recently. The next day after prescribing routine formula feed, parents come to you with child developing urticaria on the whole body. The best feed to replace the previous formula feed is?
questions.solution:
• This child is likely to be allergic to cow’s milk protein and will need to be treated with a feed that is free of cow’s milk protein.
  • The first choice is a hydrolysate in which the protein is pre-digested.
  • Soya formula should not be used in the infants under 6 months of age and in any case, there is a significant cross reactivity.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2122

choices.text: At least 6 cafe au lait patches

questions.text: In neurofibromatosis type I, which of the following features are present in the majority of affected individuals by adulthood?
questions.solution:
• 6 or more café au lait patches are usually present by 4 years of age.
  • Large plexiform neurofibromas occur in 5-10% by adulthood.
  • Cranial MRI show optic glioma in around 15%.
  • Acoustic neuromas are feature of type II and not type I.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2874

choices.text: 21-hydroxylase deficiency in a child with 46, XX karyotype
Partial androgen insensitivity in a child with 46, XY karyotype

questions.text: All are causes of ambiguous genitals except?
questions.solution:
• Smith-lemli-opitz syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder of cholesterol biosynthesis which is a cause of ambiguous genitals in boys.
  • Chromosomal males with 21-hydroxylase deficiency are normal boys at birth. Where as females presents with masculinized genitals.
  • Complete androgen insensitivity in males will present as a female while partial androgen insensitivity in males will present as an incompletely masculinized genitals.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2751

questions.text: The normal sister of a boy with Tay-Sach's disease has asked for her risk of being a carrier for the condition. What is the most appropriate answer?
questions.solution:
• It is an autosomal recessive condition. To have an affected brother, both her parents must be carriers. In each pregnancy her parents had a 1 in 4 chance of having an affected child, 2 in 4 chances of having a carrier and 1 in 4 chances of having a completely unaffected child who is not a carrier. Given that sister is unaffected, we remove the 1st possibility and the other 2 possibility still remains. Hence, she has 2 in 3 chance (66%) of being a carrier.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 584

choices.text: To check her chromosome and proceed with routine maternal serum screening and anomaly scanning if they are normal
To offer chorionic villus sampling for chromosome at 11-week gestation
To offer amniocentesis testing for chromosome at 16 weeks gestation
To offer detailed cardiac scanning at 22 weeks gestation

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman who is pregnant tells you she had a sister who died as a baby from a severe atrioventricular septal defect associated with Down syndrome. She has no further information but is concerned about her own risk for having a child with Down syndrome. The most appropriate course of action is which of the following?
questions.solution:
• It is most likely that her sister had straightforward trisomy 21. However, the small possibility that it was translocation Down syndrome cannot be excluded, so her chromosome should be checked. If they are normal, then she is not at any significantly increased risk compared with background risk, and only routine screening is appropriate.
  • If found to carry a Robertsonian translocation involving chromosome 21 then she should be offered fetal karyotyping by chorionic villous sampling or amniocentesis.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 584

choices.text: Endocrine testing for growth hormone levels and pituitary function
Assessment of sitting and standing heights and arm span

questions.text: In a child with disproportionate short stature the investigation most likely to be helpful diagnostically is which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Although achondroplasia is a common cause of disproportionate short stature it is not the only one. It can be diagnosed reliably by skeletal survey as can many other causes.
  • Growth hormone deficiency is not associated with disproportionate short stature.
  • Measuring sitting and standing height with arm span can only confirm the disproportionated nature and not the cause.

Ref. Nelson’s Paediatric Symptom based diagnosis, pg. 791

questions.text: Most common cardiac complication with Noonan syndrome is?
questions.solution:
• The most frequent cardiac abnormality with Noonan syndrome is pulmonary stenosis, often associated with a dysplastic valve.
  • Other recognized cardiac abnormalities are hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and septal defects.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2747

choices.text: Hereditary spherocytosis is confirmed by presence of spherocytes in peripheral smear and by chromosome fragility test
G6PD deficiency and pyruvate kinase deficiency are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner
The Embden-Meyerhof pathway is unable to function in a red cell that is deficient in G6PD
G6PD deficiency is confirmed by assaying the red cell G6PD enzyme

questions.text: Which of the following statements are correct about hemolytic anemias?
questions.solution:
• Hereditary spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant condition. Spherocytes are seen on the blood smear but the laboratory confirmation test is Osmotic fragility and not chromosome fragility.
  • G6PD is inherited in X linked recessive manner while pyruvate kinase deficiency is inherited as autosomal recessive manner.
  • G6PD can be confirmed by demonstrating inadequate levels of G6PD enzyme activity in red cells.
  • The Embden-Meyerhof pathway is associated with the metabolism to glucose to lactate. G6PD is an enzyme required to generate reducing power from Glucose-6-phosphate in the HMP shunt- an offshoot from the main Embden-Meyerhof pathway. Therefore, in G6PD deficiency the Embden-Meyerhof pathway is intact while the HMP shunt is not.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 716

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is presented to you with complaints of mild cough. On examination there is pallor. He is the first-born child of parents who are distantly related. His younger sister is 6-month-old who is well and thriving. His diet consists of cows milk, fortified cereals and occasionally vegetables and red meat. His CBC shows: Hb 9.0 g/dL, MCV 58 fL, MCH 20 pg, MCHC 28 g/dl, platelets 2.6 lakhs/μL, RBC count 5.5. which of the following is the MOST likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• All of the given options are causes of microcytic hypochromic anemia. Among all the most common causes are Iron deficiency anemia and Thalassemia trait.
  • In this case, if the dietary history is reliable, iron deficiency anemia is possible, but not likely.
  • The parents of the patient are distantly related and may be carriers of thalassemia and hence thalassemia trait is a definite possibility.
  • The platelet count in iron deficiency anemia is normally elevated or is at least at the upper range of normal, while the RBC count is low.
  • On the other hand, the RBC count is normally elevated in thalassemia trait while Hb is low but not as low as seen in iron deficiency anemia. For the above reasons, most likely diagnosis is Thalassemia trait.

Ref. Nelson’s Paediatric Symptom based diagnosis, pg. 665

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with 4-week history of a low-grade fever, signs of URTI, bilateral lower limb pain, cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy, a mediastinal mass and petechiae. CBC shows pancytopenia. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• ALL generally presents with signs and symptoms related to bone marrow failure, i.e., anemia, thrombocytopenia and secondary effects of leukopenia. In addition, patients can present with extramedullary signs such as lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly and splenomegaly.
  • Bone pain, often presenting as a limp in younger child, may be a presentation of presumed lymphoblast infiltration of marrow cavity.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2437

questions.text: Which of the following is false statement regarding Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is X linked.
  • There is a classic triad of thrombocytopenia, eczema and immunodeficiency.
  • Associated features include vasculitis and autoimmunity and a predisposition to lymphoproliferative diseases in later life.
  • Th underlying defect is due to loss of WAS protein which is important for cytoskeletal organization and cell motility.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2405

questions.text: A 2-year-old infant presents with a 3-day history of high fever without localizing signs. She suffers a short self-limiting febrile convulsion and is admitted for observation. The next day fever subsides but maculopapular rash develops over the trunk and abdomen. Which of the following is MOST likely virus responsible?
questions.solution:
• The pattern of 3-day fever without an obvious cause is characteristic. Febrile seizures are relatively common mode of presentation. the roseola rash often appears as fever subsides and may be macular or maculopapular and usually begins centrally spreading later to the limbs and resolving in 48-72 hours.
  • Measles may have similar presentation, but the timing and fever pattern favors more HHV6.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1594

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with recurrent deep skin infections. His mother reports about delayed separation of umbilical cord. He is under dental treatment for periodontitis. I & D of the infected skin infection showed minimal pus drain and had delayed wound healing. His CBC is Hb 12.2, WBC 19.8, differential is 65/30, Platelet count is 4.56 lacs. An immune deficiency disease is suspected. Which of the following is most likely?
questions.solution:
• The history is characteristic of a neutrophil defect.
  • Chronic granulomatous disease may be present in this manner and a Nitro-blue tetrazolium test should be performed to differentiate but we expect pus at the site of infection.
  • The finding of delayed cord separation favors more LAD type 1. This is a defect of CD18 molecule on neutrophils and lymphocytes which leads to impaired cell migration. Thus, there is usually a persistent neutrophilia, but as cells are unable to target migration to the site of infection, very little pus formation occurs.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1044

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy has severe periorbital cellulitis. He has history of similar infection and is troubled by recurrent bouts of oral ulcers. His mother also has history of recurrent oral ulcers and gingivitis. Most likely diagnosis among following is?
questions.solution:
• In cyclical neutropenia, during the neutropenic nadir, many patients suffer from malaise, fever, oral and genital ulcers, gingivitis, periodontitis, or pharyngitis, and occasionally lymph node enlargement. More serious infections may occasionally occur, including pneumonia, mastoiditis, and intestinal perforation with peritonitis leading to life-threatening clostridial sepsis.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1051

choices.text: Start diuretics and admit for observation
Start digoxin and diuretic and see in the clinic in 3-month time

questions.text: A 1-month-old boy is brought to the ER with complaints of breathlessness and poor feeding increasing progressively in last 1 week. On examination, there is hepatomegaly, respiratory rate of 60/min, active precordium with soft murmur. Oxygen saturation is 94% on air and good femoral pulse. Most appropriate next treatment is?
questions.solution:
• Clinical features in the vignette are consistent with a large VSD. Large VSD always develops into pulmonary hypertension. Affected children gets symptomatic after 1 week of age.
  • There can be either a soft or no systolic murmur and an apical mid-diastolic murmur.
  • Immediate management is giving Diuretics and observing for any worsening.
  • In long term they should be treated with digoxin and diuretics for 3 months and later plan for surgical closure. Treatment modality depends on severity of the symptoms.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2196

choices.text: Are always due to normal flow around the heart and never due to cardiac pathology
Can be a soft diastolic murmur at the left sternal edge
Children with innocent murmur should have antibiotic prophylaxis prior to dental procedures
Are more likely to lead to congenital heart disease in offspring

questions.text: True statement about innocent murmur among the following is?
questions.solution:
• These are common murmurs heard in normal children. They are often discovered in children with co-existing infection or with anemia.
  • Innocent murmurs all relate to a structurally normal heart. The child is always asymptomatic. The murmur may change with posture.

Ref. Park’s textbook of Paediatric Cardiology, 6th ed., pg. 36

questions.text: What do you expect from a normally developing 3-year-old child?
questions.solution:
• Copying a cross, counting to 10 and standing on one leg is expected at 4 years of age.

Ref. Illingworth’s The development of Infant & Child

questions.text: A baby delivered at 38 weeks of gestation and weighing 1800g, develops feed intolerance and abdominal distention. The child is admitted in NICU and investigations are sent. CBC shows Hb 22g/dl and Hct 73%. Which of the following is best treatment for the condition?
questions.solution:
Polycythemia is having Hct above 2SD.

The indications of Partial exchange transfusions are

  • Hct above 75% in asymptomatic child
  • Hct above 65% in a symptomatic child

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 887

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with history of vomiting, poor appetite and poor weight gain. As a routine diagnostic workup for nutrition deficiency, an x ray of tibia and ulna was obtained as below. Probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• The X ray shows cortical hyperostosis with sparing of Metaphysis. This is a characteristic finding in Hypervitaminosis A. The clinical features also favor the findings.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 320

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents to you with complaints of fever and coughing for 10 days. The findings are as below. The organism causing this condition is?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis here is Scrub typhus and the causative organism is Orientia tsusugamushi.
  • The first picture shows the typical eschar of scrub typhus. The second image is abnormalities found in CXR in this condition. Common findings are pulmonary edema, interstitial pneumonia and hemorrhage.
  • Scrub typhus can be mild or severe in children. Most patients present with fever for 9-11 days (range: 1-30 days) before seeking medical care.
  • Regional or generalized lymphadenopathy is reported in 23-93% of patients, hepatomegaly in about two-thirds, and splenomegaly in about one-third of children with scrub typhus.
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms, including abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea, occur in up to 40% of children at presentation.
  • A single painless eschar with an erythematous rim at the site of the chigger bite is seen in 7-68% of cases, and a maculopapular rash is present in <30%; both can be absent. Hemophagocytic lympho-histiocytosis has been described. Leukocyte and platelet counts are most commonly within normal ranges, although thrombocytopenia occurs in one-quarter to one-third of children, and leukocytosis is observed in approximately 40%.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1504

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents in the ER with history of fall from 2nd floor of the building and head injury, before 4 hours. On examination his GCS score is 9/15. An immediate CT scan was done which is as follows. For this type of hemorrhage, which is the commonest vessel involved?
questions.solution:
• The image shown is typical of Extradural hematoma. And most commonly involved artery is Middle meningeal artery.
  • The closest differential for this is Subdural hematoma. But there the hemorrhage is crescent shaped.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paaediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 835

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with sudden onset bilateral loss of vision, motor weakness and seizures following a URTI. The MRI is shown as below. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• The MRI shows patchy hyperintensity in subcortical and deep white matter, in the corona radiata. This is with the symptoms are suggestive of ADEM.
  • Initial symptoms of ADEM may include lethargy, fever, headache, vomiting, meningeal signs, and seizures, including status epilepticus.
  • Encephalopathy is a hallmark of ADEM, ranging from ongoing confusion to persistent irritability to coma. Focal neurologic deficits can be difficult to ascertain in the obtunded or very young child but common neurologic signs in ADEM include visual loss, cranial neuropathies, ataxia, motor and sensory deficits, plus bladder/bowel dysfunction with concurrent spinal cord demyelination.
  • Cranial MRI, the imaging study of choice, typically exhibits large, multifocal and sometimes confluent or large edematous mass-like tumefactive T2 lesions with variable enhancement within white and often gray matter of the cerebral hemispheres, cerebellum, and brainstem.
  • Deep gray-matter structures (thalami, basal ganglia) are often involved, although this may not be specific to ADEM.
  • Closest differential is MS, where the optic neuritis is unilateral and the age of onset is after 10 years.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2924

choices.text: An Apgar score of 9 at 1 minute usually means the baby does not need resuscitation
If the Apgar score is 5 at 1 minute, then all you need to do is repeat it at 5 minutes and it will have usually gone up
Apgar scores are better than umbilical cord blood gases for assessing asphyxiated babies

questions.text: Which of the following is true about APGAR score?
questions.solution:
• Not every baby will have an Apgar score of 10 at 1 minute and if the baby is still slightly cyanosed, they may score 9, but do not need any intervention as they are usually breathing with a good heart rate.
  • Although Apgar score is not primarily used to determine the need for resuscitation, an Apgar score of 5 at 1 minute suggests the baby is likely to need intervention.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 847

choices.text: More common in males than females
Dislocatable hip can be easily abducted but not flexed

questions.text: True statement about developmental dysplasia of hip is?
questions.solution:
• Prolonged breech position antenatally can mean the hip joint does not develop properly and is a major risk for DDH and hip dislocation.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 3275

choices.text: Put the child in morning sunlight to help convert unconjugated bilirubin in more safer forms

questions.text: A 2-day old infant is presented to you with complaint of visible yellow coloration of skin. The next best step is?
questions.solution:
• Visual assessment for jaundice is very inaccurate. Hence, levels of bilirubin must be obtained through serum samples or transcutaneous bilirubinometer. The level must be compared with treatment graphs and decide about the modality of management.
  • Also, check for adequacy of feeding and any external signs of sepsis.

Ref. Avery's diseases of the newborn, 1st SA ed., pg. 1309

questions.text: Which of the following complication is commoner in preterm babies compared to full term babies?
questions.solution:
• The preterm white matter seems to be especially sensitive to ischemic injury and this is further exacerbated if there is an inflammatory response present secondary to infection (e.g., chorioamnionitis) or inflammation (e.g., NEC). Hypoxic ischemic injury is possible at any gestation but more common in term babies due to complications of labor.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 823

choices.text: Abdomen is often distended and tense

questions.text: All the following are true regarding infantile colic except?
questions.solution:
• Colic generally affects babies in the first 3 months and then usually resolves. During the episode the abdomen is distended and tense and the legs drawn up. Colic is not a reason to stop breast-feeding, but discontinuing cow's milk in the mother's diet can be helpful.

Reg. Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 8th ed., pg. 559

choices.text: Immediate reaction to child's bad behavior

questions.text: All are principles of positive behavioral management except
questions.solution:
• It is generally best to ignore the tantrum until the child calms down. If this fails then ‘time out’ can be a useful technique, which not only removes the attention the child desires, it also allows the parents time to control their own anger.
  • Setting limits, praising the child (catch them being good) and using start charts are ways to encourage good behavior.

Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 203

choices.text: Commonly occurs in child age more than 2 years
White tonsillar exudates are reliable sign of bacterial infection
Cervical adenitis is a rare but important sign

questions.text: True statement about streptococcal tonsillitis
questions.solution:
• Bacterial tonsillitis is rare in babies and toddlers, although they may have viral tonsillitis.
  • Both exudates and cervical adenitis are common findings in tonsillitis and occur in bacterial and viral infection.
  • Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a rare but important complication.

(Ref. Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2017)
